title: Hanahan mayor warns and advises residents ahead of hurricane season peak
message:
Hanahan Mayor Christie Rainwater penned a letter to residents Tuesday acknowledging community concerns about flooding and hurricane preparedness, while also advising residents on how to best stay safe during a storm.
Rainwater also shared that the city has been attempting to obtain flood insurance premium discounts for residents via the National Flood Insurance Program's (NFIP) Community Rating System.
Points are then used to reduce flood insurance premiums for policyholders.
The Hanahan Mayor claimed that residents now receive a 20 percent discount on their flood insurance premiums due to participation in the Community Rating System.
The letter comes as hurricane season reaches its peak, prompting many Lowcountry governments and emergency organizations to increase preparations for a major storm.

title: Florida on alert for tropical downpours as models shift disturbance to Gulf of Mexico
message:
For several days, model forecasts consistently indicated that the tropical wave, now known as Invest 97L, would likely move into the Atlantic.
However, by Thursday, the models have generally agreed that it will now track into the Gulf of Mexico.
While the forecast intensity is still uncertain, we may see a tropical depression, tropical storm or potentially a hurricane.
Regardless, this track places Florida on the dirty side of the system, which translates into numerous tropical downpours heading to Central Florida from late weekend into early next week.
As of Thursday morning, the NHC says the tropical wave has a medium (60%) chance for development over the next seven days.

title: Vermont Inundated as 1 - in - 1 , 000 - Year Rainfall Event Destroys Homes , Prompts Rescues
message:
The aftermath of flash flooding on Red Village Road in Lyndonville, Vermont on July 30 2024.
Nearly eight inches of rain fell in only six hours in St. Johnsbury — considered a one in a thousand year event, CNN reported.
I had no idea this was coming,” said one of the town’s residents Vanessa Allen, as reported by The Associated Press.
Lyndonville and St. Johnsbury, located near state capital Montpelier, got the brunt of the flooding.
Vermont Emergency Management said about two dozen rescues had been executed in the area by 10 swift-water rescue teams.

title: Do you rent ? You may be more vulnerable to climate - driven disasters
message:
Disasters cause a cascade of financial problems for rentersPeople who rent face unique challenges after weather disasters.
As a result, in the immediate aftermath of a disaster, renters often face huge bills, starting with rent itself.
Ryan Kellman / NPR / NPR A building lists towards the water along Big Pine Island Road in Matlacha, Fla., as the sun sets in June.
“Disaster creates disaster,” James says.
Ryan Kellman / NPR / NPR After the storm Venus James and her husband relocated to outside Tampa.

title: State Affairs committee looks into power outages after Hurricane Beryl
message:
Hurricane Beryl is gone and most of the power line repair work is done in Houston.
On Wednesday, members of the House State Affairs Committee brought back the CEO of CenterPoint Energy, Jason Wells, who issued another apology for how the power provider responded to the power outage.
Committee members expressed their frustration with the answers they've been getting, especially regarding how power poles are maintained.
Those trees were not part of the CenterPoint vegetation reduction plan.
Wells told the committee more than 40 policy changes have been made, or are in the process of being implemented.

title: Severe Storms in the Southeast US Leave 1 Dead and Cause Widespread Power Outages
message:
CANTON, Ga.—A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
Wednesday’s remaining outages were most concentrated around the town of Ellijay in the north Georgia mountains.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city’s downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.

title: Stormy Weather and Climate Change This Week
message:
And yes, that event was climate change enhanced in at least two ways, maybe three.
All in all, it is likely that South Carolina, the neighbor of the state that is famous for making climate change illegal, and who's congressional delegation refused to help the victims of Super Storm Sandy, got walloped by climate change.
But this is yet another case of the tropics breaking out of their usual pattern as a result, likely, of climate change combined with this year's ongoing El Nino.
Disturbance Number 1, just getting going, has about a 50% chance of becoming a tropical storm over the next five days.
In case you were wondering about the climate change - hurricane link, this might be of interest to you:

title: Non - Shocking Update For Western Montana Bitterroot River
message:
If anything should close a portion of a river to the public, that's probably as good of an example as any.
Clark Fork and Blackfoot River closures were lifted earlier this week.
The July 24 severe thunderstorm in the Missoula area caused extensive damage to power lines, trees, and property in the west-central Montana area.
The Aftermath of the Severe Thunderstorm in Missoula, Montana - July 2024 The National Weather Service cited 80 mph winds at the Missoula Montana Airport and over 100 mph winds at the apex of Mount Sentinel.
Powerful winds left behind a path of broken trees, downed power lines, failing traffic lights, and debris as far as the eye can see.

title: Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone :  We are not just in a fire season , we are in a fire year
message:
Officials declare California wildfires have burned 5 times more area this year alone: 'We are not just in a fire season, we are in a fire year'Wildfires in California burned more than 300,000 acres through the third week of July.
It is still relatively early in California's wildfire season, but it is unfortunately already off to a roaring start.
Through the third week of July, the number of acres burned had nearly tripled the average of the past five years, according to Cal Fire.
There have been more than 4,000 wildland fires and over 2,500 structural fires in California so far.
Why is an active wildfire season in California important?

message:

title: A Vermont sheriff has lost his driveway to flood waters twice in one month
message:
Three weeks ago, the remains of Hurricane Beryl swept through northern Vermont, sending violent flood waters into homes and businesses and washing away roadways.
Jennifer Hemond said the couple’s home insurance does not cover flooding to a driveway.
A National Weather Service flood watch was in effect for central and northern Vermont from noon until midnight.
Jennifer Hemond said a local group is trying to raise money to help residents in the Northeast Kingdom affected by the floods.
Jennifer Hemond said the challenges of the past month added to an already stressful time, as she worried about her husband’s health.

title: Charleston County prepares for severe storms with emergency exercise
message:
NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. (WCSC) - Multiple agencies participated in Charleston County’s full-scale exercise to simulate a hurricane and determine the best response strategies.
The Charleston County emergency management team, plus more than 110 people from law enforcement, EMS and public works participated in an emergency exercise Wednesday at the Emergency Operations Center.
Each year, county officials look at ways to not only add to their emergency plan but also refine it to ensure its effectiveness.
Interim Director for Emergency Management for Charleston County Ben Webster explains how these exercises test their abilities.
“It gets everyone in the same room, it gets everybody communicating, making sure that plan works, making sure that communication structure works and making sure that command structure works,” Webster said.

title: IOP first responders take part in full - scale exercise to prepare for hurricanes
message:
ISLE OF PALMS, S.C. (WCBD) – First responders on the Isle of Palms put their hurricane response skills to the test on Wednesday during a full-scale exercise involving an imaginary storm.
IOP police officers busted through the doors of a room inside of the resort, which jumpstarted the exercise.
First responders quickly tended to the four volunteers pretending to be victims who sustained injuries amid the chaos.
After a few minutes, the helicopter landed, Maynard was loaded inside, and they were back in the air again, marking the end of the exercise.
The simulation was part of a larger multi-day exercise conducted by the Charleston County Emergency Management Department.

title: B . C . issues flood warning , watches after landslide blocks river , forces evacuations – Winnipeg Free Press
message:

The River Forecast Centre has issued a flood warning for the Chilcotin River upstream of the landslide and a flood watch downstream.

title: A moving monster : How did the Jasper fire get so bad , so fast ?
message:
By Wednesday night, fires had reached Jasper, with flames and smoke so intense it forced first responders to briefly retreat.
Questions and accusations have followed, including from critics who argue Parks Canada and other government agencies did not do enough to protect Jasper.
What were some of the major drivers of the Jasper wildfire?
Despite the shortcomings, Parks Canada has become one of the most active agencies in Canada for prescribed burns, said Bourbonnais.
But he praised the preparedness in Jasper and said all requests for more wildfire support had been approved.

title: Valley News - Why does Vermont keep flooding ? It complicated , but experts warn it could become the norm
message:
Vermont is flooding.
Warming atmosphereExtreme flooding conditions like these are often the result of random, short-term natural weather patterns heightened by long-term, human-caused climate change.
With climate change, storms are forming in a warmer atmosphere, making extreme rainfall a more frequent reality.
Heavily manipulated riversVermont’s history of heavily manipulating its rivers and streams also plays a role in increased flooding, Vermont Agency of Natural Resources secretary Julie Moore said.
A crumbling dam systemDams in Vermont are increasingly at risk as climate change brings heavier rains and more powerful storms.

title: Unrelenting heat to keep US sweating during final month of summer
message:
Unrelenting heat to keep US sweating during final month of summerThe scorching heat is expected to continue through the end of an already sweltering summer, according to NOAA’s latest climate forecast for August 2024.
NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center issued its 30-day outlook for August – the final full month of summer – and it looks like Americans are in for much of the same above-average heat that has dominated this summer so far.
People walk along the coast as the sun sets on the Pacific Ocean at Windansea Beach in La Jolla during a summer heat wave on July 23, 2024 in San Diego, California.
An active hurricane season in the Atlantic – with a possible new tropical system approaching the Southeast during the first week of August – could easily bring enough rain to exceed monthly normal precipitation for the final month of summer.
Original article source: Unrelenting heat to keep US sweating during final month of summer

The scorching heat is expected to continue through the end of an already sweltering summer, according to NOAA’s latest climate forecast for August 2024.
NOAA’s Climate Prediction Center issued its 30-day outlook for August – the final full month of summer – and it looks like Americans are in for much of the same above-average heat that has dominated this summer so far.
August US temperature outlookNOAA’s temperature outlook shows above-average temperatures across most of the contiguous US and the northeast half of Alaska.
The Plains, Southeast and Gulf Coast states are forecast to begin August with a heat wave bringing dangerous heat to those regions through next week.

title: House members demand solutions from CenterPoint in the wake of failures during Beryl – Houston Public Media
message:
Screenshot/Texas HouseCenterPoint CEO Jason Wells faced another day of questioning from Texas lawmakers regarding the utility's response to Hurricane Beryl.
Committee Vice Chair Ana Hernandez (D-Houston) took Wells to task over the company's failures before, during, and after Beryl.
That included the question of how CenterPoint planned to accelerate its process of replacing wooden poles with more durable ones by the end of the hurricane season.
"It was a little over 3,000 poles," Wells said, "and we have about 1.2 million on our distribution system, and we can do better, and we will do better by replacing those wooden poles with composite poles."
Further, Wells said the company expects to replace just 1,000 wooden poles with composite ones by year's end.

title: Cape Fear residents prepare as tropical wave moves through the Caribbean
message:
Cape Fear residents prepare as tropical wave moves through the CaribbeanLELAND, NC (WWAY) — Meteorologists are closely watching the Caribbean, as a tropical wave makes its way to the US.
On Wednesday, WWAY went to the Ace Hardware on Village Rd.
For now, its too early to tell if the wave will develop into tropical storm Debby, or if it will head toward the Cape Fear.
We do have the hurricane items that we usually bring out front,” Barker said.
To stay informed on the tropical wave, you can visit our daily forecast.

title: Smoke Advisory extended ; monsoonal moisture arrives Thursday
message:
The Smoke Advisory has been extended for parts of Riverside County due to elevated fine particle pollution in the air from wildfire smoke.
A ridge of high pressure to our east will expand west and begin to steer monsoonal moisture into Southern California.
Any storm that develops could bring heavy rain, lightning, and gusty winds.
The storm chances decrease for the weekend but remain in the forecast for the mountains and deserts through the middle of next week.
This weekend will also bring more heat, prompting an Excessive Heat Watch to be issued for Saturday and Sunday.

title: Caribbean conservationists urge greater focus on disaster risk management
message:
Caribbean conservationists are encouraging small island developing states (SIDS) to place greater attention on disaster risk management and prevention measures, so that the appropriate strategies are in place and actionable before the countries are devastated by natural disasters.
Speaking at a Global Conservation Connection webinar on Tuesday under the topic ‘Disaster Risk Management and Hurricanes in the Caribbean’, keynote speaker Dr Trevor Johnson Jr, from The Bahamas, a consultant with the Inter-American Development Bank and a regional disaster management specialist with the Pacific Disaster Center, stated that issues surrounding disaster management should be at the forefront of the agenda of all governments within the Caribbean region.
He argued that as disasters impacted every socio-economic sector, deliberate, laser-focused and pragmatic regional discourse is necessary, and that the issues of disaster risk management demand a full community approach.
“Disaster risk management is everyone’s business,” he said.
She continued that St Lucia has had challenges with disaster risk management, particularly in the town of Soufrière, which is extremely vulnerable to hurricanes and storm surge damages.

title: Gulf Coast : Check your trees for storm readiness before the next storm hits
message:
Gulf Coast: Check your trees for storm readiness — before the next storm hitsBALDWIN COUNTY, Ala. (WKRG) — It’s not “if” a hurricane will hit our area, it’s “when”.
Before that happens, experts ask that people look up and check if their trees can weather the storm.
Okaloosa County suspect in spider’s death arrested“Whole trees came down right from the roots,” that was during Hurricane Sally and since then Jack Ruck has been concerned about some of his trees.
Norah O’Donnell leaving as anchor of CBS evening newscast after electionHe brought that concern to a workshop where Certified Arborist and Extension Agent Joel Potter said now is the time to check your trees.
The root system is also very important but so is what’s above the roots.

title: Croatia reports its toughest day for firefighters as Balkan nations battle wildfires in a heat wave
message:
Croatia’s Firefighters’ Association said the demanding 24-hour period included responding to more than 100 fires with over 1,000 firefighters and 20 firefighting planes.
In North Macedonia, some 66 wildfires erupted over the past 24 hours.
Firefighters gather near the wildfire in Tucepi, Croatia, late Tuesday, July 30, 2024.
Countries like North Macedonia, Bulgaria and Albania have all sought help from abroad.
Firefighters gather near the wildfire in Tucepi, Croatia, late Tuesday, July 30, 2024.

title: Megan Forecast : Turning up the heat and humidity
message:
It's about to be feeling a lot more tropical in San Diego as monsoon flow returns bringing high humidity and a chance of showers and thunderstorms.
High pressure over Texas will expand west, ushering in warmer and more humid conditions that will stick around well into next week.
The deserts will see the return of excessive heat with an Excessive Heat Watch issued for Saturday and Sunday.
Expect high temperatures between 113 and 117 degrees and morning lows only dipping into the mid-80s to low-90s.
The high heat and above-normal temperatures are expected to last through at least August 9th, with less hot and humid conditions expected to follow.

title: Powerful bow echo slams Omaha with hurricane - force winds
message:
– Severe thunderstorms rocked eastern Nebraska and southwestern Iowa on Wednesday, causing widespread power outages in the Omaha metro area.
Tree damage after storms rolled through Omaha, Nebraska on July 31, 2024Wind gusts around Omaha's Eppley Airfield, the region’s busiest airport, reached 90 mph.
"The windstorm that struck the OPPD service territory caused power outages to 220,545 customers," OPPD stated Wednesday night.
Despite the flurry of severe weather, local authorities did not report any deaths associated with the event.
Original article source: Powerful bow echo slams Omaha with hurricane-force winds

title: FIRST ALERT : Tropical development still likely this weekend or early next week
message:
MYRTLE BEACH, SC (WMBF) - An area of disturbed weather continues to approach the Bahamas and may develop into a tropical depression or tropical storm by this weekend or early next week.
Development of this system is unlikely during the next couple of days while it moves west-northwestward over portions of the Greater Antilles.
The chance of development sits at 20% over the next two days and 60% over the next five days.
Right now, a westward trend of this system looks to bring impacts closer to Florida or even the Gulf of Mexico next week.
Areas in the Gulf of Mexico and near Florida should monitor this chance of development closely.

title: Met Office on weather triple whammy as thunderstorms , flooding , and 30C temperatures set to sweep united kingdom
message:
The Met Office has issued a yellow weather warning over thunderstorms that will bring heavy rainfall and the risk of flooding to parts of the UK on ThursdayBrace yourselves for a wild weather ride, as the Met Office is warning of thunderstorms and hail lashing parts of the UK today, amid scorching temperatures already reaching up to 30C in many parts.
With heatwave temperatures, storm clouds, and flooding on the horizon, some could see a triple whammy of extreme weather on Thursday.
This follows two days of heatwave temperatures, which has seen many in the UK finally get a taste of hot summer weather.
Image: Getty Images) Getty Images)Central, southern, and eastern England, along with South Wales, are set to face scattered but intense showers and thunderstorms later on Thursday.
Temperatures are set to soar up to 30C from Hampshire to north London, while western Scotland is expected to experience the day's coolest temperatures, ranging between 17C and 18C.

title: Wildfire safety tips from experts
message:
If you’re completely overrun by fire, take shelter inside your vehicle – you’re going to be much better off than outside of the vehicle.
If you’re trapped outside during a wildfireThe Oak Fire burns through trees on July 24, 2022, near Jerseydale, California.
If you're trapped outdoors in a fire, try to find downhill escape routes.
Justin Sullivan/Getty ImagesIf you’re trapped outdoors with a wildfire approaching, call 911 and give them your exact location, Heggie said.
Mott said we should think ahead and prepare for wildfire but also “don’t worry yourself sick about it.

title: Alabama Closely Monitoring Possible Tropical Depression Formation
message:

We are paying attention to a tropical wave with a 60 percent chance of developing over the next 7 days.

title: Severe storms in the Southeast US leave 1 dead and caus ...
message:
CANTON, Ga. (AP) — A weather system that produced severe thunderstorms late into the night in the Southeast left one man dead in Georgia, caused damage in a South Carolina town and left hundreds of thousands of electricity customers without power for a time.
Power outages in southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia had declined to about 30,000 by Wednesday morning, down from more than 200,000 in Georgia alone.
Wednesday's remaining outages were most concentrated around the town of Ellijay in the north Georgia mountains.
In Orangeburg, South Carolina, straight-line winds caused damage in the city's downtown district, blowing down metal from roofs and wood from awnings of downtown businesses.
Officials across southeastern Tennessee and northern Georgia said roads were blocked Wednesday because of downed trees and power lines.

title: Strong - to - severe storms could snarl rush hour in Chicago area – NBC Chicago
message:
The Chicago area could wake up to strong-to-severe thunderstorms on Thursday, with the National Weather Service’s Storm Prediction Center upgrading the region to a “slight” risk of severe weather.
Any storms that do develop could still produce rain and gusty winds, but may not reach severe limits.
The threat of rain in the Chicago area could stick around into Friday, as an area of low-pressure spins over Lake Michigan, shifting winds out of the north and bringing a few different waves of rain to the region.
It isn’t likely severe weather will develop from that system, but some embedded storms could form.
The next chance of rain doesn’t emerge until Tuesday, with temperatures cooling off after that system moves through.

title: A Severe Thunderstorm Watch has Been Issued
message:
CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa (KCRG) - A Severe Thunderstorm Watch has been issued for our western counties until 1 a.m.Current severe weather alerts from the National Weather Service.
(KCRG)Your First Alert: More severe storm chances late this evening into tonightStorms are likely tonight, with a threat of severe weather once again.
The Storm Prediction Center includes most of the viewing area in a slight risk for severe weather with this activity, with the chances somewhat higher in central and western Iowa.
Severe Weather Outlook (KCRG)Storm Timing (KCRG)Flash flooding could develop in spots today with the potential for heavy rainfall.
The threat for severe weather looks lower, but be ready for a potential brief period of rain and some lightning to move through at times.

title: Live updates : Storms blast Omaha , closing Eppley Airfield , leaving 191 , 000 without power
message:
Massive trees were downed, branches fell inside houses and neighborhoods roared with the sounds of chainsaws beginning to clear the damage.
Neighbors helped each other drag tree branches out of the road and survey damage to houses, which included downed fences, dislodged shingles on roofs and massive tree branches that narrowly missed vehicles.
7:20 p.m.| The current power outage figures rival previous, memorable widespread Omaha power outages.
Water pooled on the ground, tree branches swayed and several different sirens sounded through downtown.
As of 6 p.m., 61,000 Omaha Public Power District customers were without power, according to OPPD's outage alerts.

title: Live updates : Storms blast Omaha , closing Eppley Airfield , leaving 191 , 000 without power
message:
Storms creating damaging wind gusts of 90 miles per hour, sideways rain and house-rattling thunder left at least 216,000 without power in the Omaha metro Wednesday evening, according to Omaha Public Power District's power outage alerts.
Neighbors helped each other drag tree branches out of the road and survey damage to houses, which included downed fences, dislodged shingles on roofs and massive tree branches that narrowly missed vehicles.
7:20 p.m.| The current power outage figures rival previous, memorable widespread Omaha power outages.
Water pooled on the ground, tree branches swayed and several different sirens sounded through downtown.
As of 6 p.m., 61,000 Omaha Public Power District customers were without power, according to OPPD's outage alerts.

title: In the US , Disasters Strike All Over the Country
message:
But a study from the nonprofit Rebuild by Design and New York University says disasters happen everywhere across the country.
The study looks at information on hundreds of federally declared disasters from 2011 to about 2021.
The study finds that eight of the nine counties with the most federally declared disasters since 2011 are in Kentucky.
Disasters in unexpected placesIn July 2022, at least 40 people died, and 300 homes were damaged when a flood struck Floyd County in eastern Kentucky.
Since 2011, FEMA has paid more than $41 billion in aid following hurricanes, the most of any kind of disaster.

title: Tropical Track Shifts Toward Gulf - Louisiana Could Feel Effects
message:
Forecasters with the National Hurricane Center have been monitoring a tropical wave as it moved across the Atlantic Ocean.
Here is the track forecast from the early morning hours of July 31st.
NHC.noaa.gov NHC.noaa.gov loading...Over the past 12 to 24 hours track model forecasts have shifted more to the west.
One tropical model is particularly troublesome as it suggests the system will enter the Gulf of Mexico, strengthen, and then approach the Florida Panhandle.
By the way, should the system earn a name as a tropical storm it would be called Debby.

title: Live updates : Severe storms blast Omaha , leaving 216 , 000 without power
message:
The massive wind storm brought down trees and branches, knocked over power lines and lifted heavy objects.
Weather service: 'Peaceful weekend ahead'5:11 a.m.| Storm recovery workers will have good weather in which to work, the National Weather Service in Valley said Thursday morning.
7:20 p.m. | The current power outage figures rival previous, memorable widespread Omaha power outages.
A flood advisory due to excessive rainfall is also in effect until 9:15 p.m., according to the weather service.
As of 6 p.m., 61,000 Omaha Public Power District customers were without power, according to OPPD's outage alerts.

title: Canton to relocate fire department with federal funds after repeated flooding
message:
After a long wait, financial help for Canton is working its way through the U.S. Congress.
A total of $5.8 million is in the pipeline in Washington, D.C. to come to Canton for the fire department to move out of the flood plain.
It was August 17, 2021, when remnants of Tropical Storm Fred swamped downtown Canton, including the fire station, nearby town hall and police department.
The height of the water inside the station is marked on the wall from Hurricane Ivan and Tropical Storms Frances and Fred.
"We had nine feet of water, 12 feet and then five feet last time with Fred," Wheeler said.

title: News Wrap : 1 dead in Colorado Stone Canyon wildfire
message: In our news wrap Wednesday, one person has been killed in a wildfire in Colorado, more storms are in the forecast as Vermont residents clean up the mess left by debilitating rain and flooding, Venezuelan President Maduro asked his country's Supreme Court to audit the contested presidential election and the Biden administration announced proposals aimed at stopping the flow of fentanyl from Mexico.

title: Technically at war , South Korea offers flood relief to North Korea
message:
South Korea is ready to provide North Korea with relief supplies for damage caused by recent heavy rainfall, South Korea’s Red Cross said on Thursday, marking a rare outreach under the administration of President Yoon Suk Yeol to its neighbour.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un personally inspected the flooded areas and expressed grave concern over the damage, state media said on Monday.
There is a possibility of “significant human casualties” in North Korea, a Unification Ministry official said on Thursday.
North Korea has cut off all lines of official communication with the South.
More rain was forecast for Sinuiju on Thursday and early Friday, according to South Korea’s weather agency.

title: Wild flamingos spotted in Georgia
message:
“Now we have another new species on the island which is really cool,” amateur naturalist Joshua Wicker said.
When Joshua Wicker and his family visited St. Simons Island a few weeks ago, they were tickled pink by what they saw.
“They’re up on a big marsh on the inside of the island, and it was just like, ‘Oh there it is!’”During the trip, Wicker spotted five flamingos hanging out in the water.
This is Georgia,” Wicker thought when he first saw them.
If you’re interested in learning more about wildlife in the area, Joshua Wicker offers entertaining and educational videos on his page, Y’all, Be Looking!

title: South Korea ? 14 new dams initiative sparks mixed reactions from residents , local governments
message:
In regions frequently affected by torrential rains, the plan was welcomed, while significant concerns arose in areas that have previously experienced negative impacts from dam construction.
The 14 candidate sites for the dams include nine locations proposed by local governments and five selected by the ministry.
Mixed reactions to dam plansAreas that frequently suffer from flooding during torrential rains welcomed the government's dam initiative.
Similarly, local governments in Daegu and North Gyeongsang Province, which have long advocated for dam construction, are supportive of the new plans.
Environmental groups are voicing strong opposition to the government's dam construction plan, questioning its effectiveness and warning of potential ecological damage.

title: Update : Damaging winds anticipated with thunderstorms in Dale and Houston counties Wednesday
message:
The National Weather Service issued an updated severe thunderstorm warning at 7:11 p.m. on Wednesday in effect until 7:30 p.m. for Dale and Houston counties.
The weather service adds, "For your protection move to an interior room on the lowest floor of a building.
Unfortunately, lightning is responsible for claiming the lives of approximately 20 people annually, as reported by the weather service.
Mastering wet roads: Safety tips for heavy rainfallWhen heavy rain pours, the risk of flooding and treacherous roads rises.
Advance Local Weather Alerts is a service provided by United Robots, which uses machine learning to compile the latest data from the National Weather Service.

title: Earthquakes equalize late , but Galaxy score in 89th minute , steal win
message:
SAN JOSE — The San Jose Earthquakes certainly had opportunities for another season-defining Leagues Cup win against the LA Galaxy on Wednesday.
San Jose finally equalized in the 75th minute on Jeremy Ebobisse’s strike in the box, but Los Angeles responded with substitute Miguel Berry’s tap-in off a Miki Yamane assist in the 89th minute.
San Jose needs a Galaxy win of any kind to guarantee a spot in the Leagues Cup’s 32-team knockout round.
But if they can carry their increased quality of play from the Leagues Cup forward, things may be different down the stretch.
Yet it could be a step in the right direction, one that eventually leads to San Jose breathing rarefied air once again.

title: 2 . 2 magnitude earthquake shakes Hunterdon County in New Jersey
message:
TEWKSBURY TOWNSHIP, N.J. (PIX11) – Maria Hadley has had enough earthquakes for a while.
“I woke my husband and I’m like, ‘earthquake!’ and he’s like, ‘what?’ I’m like, ‘earthquake!’ He goes, ‘you’re dreaming, go back to sleep.
'”More New Jersey NewsAccording to the USGS, another earthquake struck early Wednesday in Tewksbury Township, just a few minutes away from Hadley’s home, registering at 2.2 magnitude.
When a 4.8 magnitude earthquake rocked the northeast on April 5, many of her plates and fine china crashed to the ground.
More Local NewsIf you live in or around Tewksbury Township, you may be curious when all this seismic activity will end.

title: August begins with hot temperatures and a few isolated thunderstorms
message:
Tonight's Forecast:Tonight will be mostly clear, but there will be some wildfire smoke in the air from fires in northern Colorado.
Plains forecast: Low: 60s; High: 90s;Mostly sunny and hot, just shy of the triple digits in the eastern plains.
Walsenburg and Trinidad forecast: Low: 60/60; High: 91/90;Mostly sunny for the first half of the day with hot temperatures.
Mountains forecast: Low: 40s/50s; High: 80s;The mountain valleys will be hot, with highs in the mid to upper-80s on Thursday.
Extended outlook forecast:Friday will be similar to Thursday with hot temperatures, a hazy sky with wildfire smoke, and a chance of afternoon thunderstorms.

title: Loudoun County farmers can apply for emergency drought aid
message:
LOUDOUN COUNTY, Va. (DC News Now) — Farmers in Loudoun County are eligible for emergency loan assistance from the federal government due to the drought during this year’s growing season.
U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Secretary Thomas Vilsack declared Loudoun and 14 other Virginia counties as “primary natural disaster areas,” allowing the Farm Service Agency (FSA) to offer emergency loans and other assistance to farmers impacted by the drought.
Farmers have eight months to apply for the loans.
Farmers in Loudoun County specifically can also receive support through the Loudoun County Department of Economic Development and Virginia Cooperative Extension.
For the latest news, weather, sports, and streaming video, head to DC News Now | Washington, DC.

title: Alf Coleman Road close to completion
message:
PANAMA CITY BEACH, Fla. (WJHG/WECP) - Alf Coleman Road is nearing completion and it has been two hundred days in the making.
“When rains come, that area does tend to flood, the road was a low point, so the water tended to collect on the road.
By raising the road, we now make sure that is passable during storm events, that important for emergency evacuation.
While Panama City Officials said that the road should be fully complete in 30 to 60 days, there should be some road closures in the meantime.
The city also has plans to make the road four lanes in the early 2030s.

title: National Hurricane Center tracking possible tropical storm formation near Bahamas , Florida – ICSF
message:
A​ disturbance in the Atlantic continues to be watched for possible formation into a tropical storm, but there are multiple scenarios in play when it comes to the track of this system as it nears the Bahamas and the southeastern United States by this weekend.
The tropical wave that might eventually grow into a tropical depression or storm is located over the Leeward Islands, or near the “X” in the graphic below, according to the National Hurricane Center.
C​omputer models suggest wind shear may be relatively light, and there’s plenty of warm ocean water ahead of this system to fuel its development near the Bahamas or the Gulf of Mexico.
However, this rather large tropical disturbance will likely have to interact with land along the way, particularly Hispaniola and Cuba, but also possibly Florida.
So, it may take some time for one area of thunderstorms to persist over water, lower surface pressure and begin the process of developing a tropical depression, if that happens at all.

title: Visitors to Rio Hondo were amazed , but these goats merely grazed
message:
A girl feeds a goat a piece of cabbage during a meet-and-greet event for the animals at Rio Hondo College on Wednesday, July 31.
(Photo by Raphael Richardson, Contributing Photographer)College officials pet a baby goat during a meet-and-greet event for the animals at Rio Hondo College on Wednesday, July 31.
(Photo by Raphael Richardson, Contributing Photographer)A college official cradles a baby goat during a meet-and-greet event for the animals at Rio Hondo College on Wednesday, July 31.
(Photo by Raphael Richardson, Contributing Photographer)A goat is fed a carrot during a meet-and-greet event for the animals at Rio Hondo College on Wednesday, July 31.
(Photo by Raphael Richardson, Contributing Photographer) ExpandWild goats roamed the campus at Río Hondo College on Wednesday, July 31.

title: I Saw Twisters And Loved It But This One Aspect Really Impacted Me
message:
Twisters is a movie I never planned to watch, at least in the theater.
Twisters could have simply been a fun movie about chasing tornadoes and tornado wrangling.
The film doesn’t really take a stand and go "maybe if people stopped doing this, then maybe there would be fewer tornadoes."
Twisters potential impact may justify its existence and maybe create a demand for more standalone sequels to '90s movies.
Could you hold on to bars in a pool and really protect yourself from flying away during a storm??

title: Arson Suspect Arrested In Forest | News Radio 1190 KEX
message:
Bureau of Land Management law enforcement rangers recently caught an arsonist who ignited a small wildfire earlier this month.
They put out the fire and called the BLM once they determined it was located on BLM land in Lane County.
BLM Law Enforcement in coordination with BLM contract deputies at the Lane County Sherif’s Office swiftly identified a suspect.
After the confession, BLM law enforcement arrested the suspected, who was booked into the Lane County Jail.
“We all need to be responsible visitors and take care of our public lands.”“Before venturing out to public lands, always check local fire restrictions,” Johnson continued.

title: B . C . issues flood warning , watches after landslide blocks river , forces evacuations
message:
A sudden release of water from the blocked Chilcotin River "may cause rapid rises in river levels downstream along the Fraser River" south to Hope, the government says.
A government statement says the landslide Wednesday blocked the river that feeds into the Fraser River, and a sudden release of water "may cause rapid rises in river levels downstream along the Fraser River" south to Hope, B.C.
The River Forecast Centre has issued a flood warning for the Chilcotin River upstream of the landslide and a flood watch downstream.
A flood watch is also in place for the Fraser River from the Chilcotin River confluence to Hope as well as a high streamflow advisory for the Fraser River west of Hope.
Evacuation orders issued Wednesday remain in place, covering 107 kilometres along both sides of the Chilcotin River, after the Cariboo Regional District said there was an immediate danger to life and safety due to flooding.

message:
— British Columbia's Ministry of Land and Water says personnel are conducting assessments near a landslide that blocked the Chilcotin River in the province's Interior, including to understand risks that might exist downstream.
